Cedric Beust wrote:

> Real code relies on dependencies all the time:
> 
> - A certain object can only be created if a previous object has been created
> before.

If so, then the previous object should be the only thing that can create 
the new object!

> - This method can only be invoked if such field has been initialized.

All objects should be in a "sane" state all the time. If not, then the 
design could be improved to avoid this problem. The Pragmatic 
Programmers call what you describe as "Programming by Coincidence".

> I am a firm believer that tests should be as close as possible to production
> code.  I don't know about you, but:
> 
> - I am nervous when I run my tests on Postgresql and the production site
> runs on Oracle.
<snip />

I am obviously not clear enough in my approach. Let me try to rectify 
that here.

As a programmer I do not want rely on Collaboration tests to prove the 
correctness of /individual objects/. Instead I want to rely on Isolation 
tests (with fakes/mocks and interface separation) for that.

I only want to use Collaboration tests when I'm worried that I might get 
the collaboration among objects wrong, such as what you describe: 
Postgresql v. Oracle. I could write a body of tests that can do double 
duty, but I would probably run the tests against HSQLDB more often than 
I run them against Oracle.

I know that /someone/ will want to use Collaboration tests extensively 
-- testers, customers, whoever -- and I don't begrudge them that, just 
as long as they don't expect me to maintain their tests.

> - I feel ever worse when my tests are using mocks, because not only are
> mocks non trivial to write (and they require you to maintain a parallel line
> of code), they can give you a deadly sense of security.  And then one day,
> your mock tests run fine but the production code breaks, and you enter a
> world of pain.  Trust me, it's not pretty.

Since I don't have this pain often enough to be serious, I must be doing 
something else -- some kind of compensating practice -- to avoid it. I 
wish I knew what that was so I could share it with everyone.

> With all that in mind, it makes sense to have a testing framework that takes
> dependencies into account and makes it as easy as possible for you to:
> 
> - Identify which test *really* broke (compare "1 SUCESS 25 FAILED" to "1
> SUCCESS 1 FAILED and 23 SKIPS").
> - Allow you to rerun the failed tests easily, including all the dependencies
> if any
> 
> These are the main features that TestNG offers (and many more of course
> :-)).

I agree that for those people who prefer to stay close to real 
dependencies, TestNG's features are great. I find my designs are cleaner 
when I try to move away from hardcoded/real dependencies towards an 
interface-rich design.

That's what makes the world great: we can get to the same place 
different ways and not want to kill each other. I wish certain countries 
would feel the same way. :)

Take care.
